III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
River Oak Youth Center is a six-bed facility located in Evart, MI. Upon entry into
River Oak there is an office to the left, a long countertop with cubbies above for
the youth on the right and a bathroom at the end of the entrance. There are two
steps on the right leading to the open kitchen/dining/living room area. There is a
large kitchen farm like table for the youth to sit at and couches and chairs in the
living area with end tables. Off from the living area is a sliding glass door leading
onto the deck and backyard. There is a volleyball net set up in the yard. At the
other end of the living area are two glass doors leading into a bonus room with
couches, a television, board games and books.
Upon walking through the kitchen area, you enter a hallway where the bedrooms,
bathrooms, and laundry services are located. The first door on the left is locked
and leads to the basement. The video monitoring equipment is in the basement
along with extra clothing for the youths, recreation equipment, and games. There
is a separate room in the basement for storage of dry goods as well as an extra
refrigerator and freeze to store food. The large holding tanks for the water for the
sprinkler system is in a separate room in the basement. Continuing down the hall,
there are two bedrooms and a bathroom on the right and two bedrooms on the
left. At the end of the hallway is a bathroom and a separate room with a washer,
dryer, and shower. The bedrooms had bunkbeds or single beds, appropriate
bedding, and curtains. There are two locked closets in the hallway as well as a
long counter with mirrors above it that can be used as a hair/makeup station for
the youth. There is a grievance box and fire extinguisher located at the end of the
hallway.
The entrance separates the living area and offices/conference rooms. There is a
hallway to the left that leads to multiple offices, a conference room, and a
multipurpose room. The offices will be occupied by the unit manager, chief
administrator, therapist, nurse, compliance director and staff. Medication will be
stored in an individual cubby for the youth that is locked as well as the entire
cubby system behind a locked cabinet door. There are four working telephones.
An environmental Health Inspection occurred on June 13, 2024, and resulted in
an “A” rating, as did the final Fire Safety Inspection conducted on June 18, 2024.
The facility has cameras throughout the building. The facility is in an area that
does not zone or approve occupancy.
5

B. Program Description
River Oak Youth Center will be providing services in a six-bed open treatment
program for females ages 10-17. Placements may extend past 17 years of age, if
the youth was in care prior to their 18th birthday. Staff will be trained in Safe Crisis
Management for de-escalation and restraint. Youth will be provided education
services by Evart Public School either at River Oak or the public school. Medical,
dental, and vision issues which are both routine and emergent in nature are
coordinated through community health providers who are responsible for the
provision of health care services and health care oversight.
The facility operates 24/7 365 days per year with 24 hour a day awake
supervision. River Oak Youth Center provides residential treatment programming
for youth who have mental health treatment and behavioral support needs that
require temporary care in a structured, supportive, and therapeutic setting. The
program is designed to be highly structured, predictable, and accepting
therapeutic community that fosters personal growth, social development and
responsibility through an array of comprehensive mental health services. Daily
group and individual therapeutic interventions are utilized to motivate, teach, and
reshape maladaptive thought processes and behavior while providing
interventions that help youth achieve emotional and behavioral stability. Services
and training provided throughout placement include behavior motivation, human
growth and development, restorative justice, life skills, mental health and
substance abuse treatment, onsite academic instruction, physical fitness and
health, pre-vocational preparation, family counseling, parenting skills, if
applicable, and community re-entry preparation. The program’s average length of
stay is approximately six to nine months.
Upon admission and initial assessment, youth are assigned a clinical treatment
track with the focus on Disruptive Behaviors or Serious Emotional Disturbance.
Full time licensed therapists are employed to deliver the primary treatment
services of individual, group, and family therapy, as well as supportive counseling
and crisis management. Psychiatric services are made available onsite through a
contracted psychiatrist. At River Oak Youth Center, treatment services are
rendered by licensed professional or master’s level therapists with requisite
professional experience and training who are working under the supervision of a
licensed mental health professional. All therapists are trained and well versed in
Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, Dialectical Behavior Therapy, Trauma Focused-
Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, and are certified as Advanced Child and
Adolescent Trauma Professionals. Therapists are assigned a primary caseload for
the provision of individual, group, and family therapy.

The agency was found in compliance.
